awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Improving bicycle helmets for children
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of properly fitted bicycle helmets for children. The proposed effort seeks to reduce head injuries. The use of poorly fitting helmets by children results in greater risk of injuries such as concussion and head injuries. This innovation also has the potential to improve fit, compliance, and safety in other applications that require helmets and other forms of personal protective equipment and may be useful for construction workers, emergency responders, military personnel, and athletes in other sports.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a bicycle helmet fit for children using 3D scanning, surface generation, mesostructure design, finite element analysis (FEA). This technology may also result in new methods of product development for personal protective equipment. The proposed process and technology involves thermoplastic mesostructures that can be repeated and additively manufactured, with comparable or improved impact resistance compared to the traditional foams used in helmets. Additively manufactured mesostructures may result in a more personalized fit,  circumventing slow, traditional helmet design and manufacturing processes and allowing for a safer, bespoke helmet that is affordable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our team joined the NSF I-Corps Program with a process for creating custom fit, 3D printed bicycle helmets and the goal of learning how to find evidence through interviews to challenge and support some initial business ideas. Our industry mentor helped us navigate new customer segments, and the I-Corps instructors advised our team on applying the business model canvas.

Intellectual Merit

During the program we completed 118 interviews and made many pivots along the way. When learning about the unique value proposition, our team started with assumptions about parents and children, and their helmet fit issues. However, through the interviews we learned that helmet fit was more than simply preventing the helmet from moving back and forth on a child’s head. Rather, the problem of helmet fit affects the amount of time the parent gets to spend with their child while riding vs. spending time adjusting the child’s helmet.

After participating in the program and having experienced the value of customer discovery firsthand, another four months of customer discovery was completed. Travel included the Military Additive Manufacturing Summit, Outdoor Retailer Show, Autodesk Conference, and Sea Otter Summit. During those months we found evidence from the interviews that challenged and supported other aspects of the business model canvas, such as customer segments, pricing, key resources, and key activities.

After finding a target market, we sized the potential opportunity of launching a new venture. We estimated the target market to be $2.5 million in revenue. Then, we reviewed several industry reports and found the Serviceable Addressable Market, specifically looking at US sporting goods head protection is estimated at $467 million in revenue. In addition, we found the Total Addressable Market, including head protection for US sporting goods, industrial, military/aerospace, and medical applications estimated to be $1.2 billion in revenue.

Finally, Dr. Makowski defended his dissertation in the Fall of 2023 where he reviewed the NSF I-Corps experience and training extensively. In addition, in his dissertation he compared the methodologies used by the NSF to other entrepreneurial methodologies.

Broader Impact

We leveraged a portion of the NSF I-Corps program funds as matching funds for Dr. Makowski’s Presidential Innovation Postdoctoral Fellowship at Virginia Tech. For this prestigious program, Dr. Makowski has been able to continue validating product and business feasibility. To quantify the value of helmet fit for the target market, Dr. Makowski is currently in the process of writing a literature review on evaluating and quantifying helmet fit. In addition, he plans to use what was learned during the NSF I-Corps program to apply for other funding, such as Virginia Innovation Partnership Corporation funds and relevant SBIR Programs.

After finding evidence from the interviews to support a business case and develop a minimum viable product, we were approved to reallocate $5,000 of our budget to R&D. So, we began product development and explored appropriate scanning technologies and created some of the first helmet designs.

The launch of a successful venture will 1.) reduce the societal burden of traumatic brain injuries, as well as 2.) boost the local economy.

1.) The launch of a custom fit helmet will allow the helmet to distribute the load, reduce pressure, and mitigate stress to the brain in a way that traditional helmets cannot. In addition, the system for improving fit will increase the likelihood the helmet is in the proper position, so the helmet can reduce and prevent traumatic brain injury during a crash, reducing the burden of neurological disease for a greater number of people. 2.) The launch of a new venture serves as a distinct opportunity for developing localized, automated production. Localized production can help with onshoring manufacturing, as well as leveraging production capabilities for other use cases. Developing localized automated production will ultimately boost the economy.
